snippet: The $1.3 billion in annual military aid to Egypt pays for the kind of weapons that its military loves, and may give America more leverage than it seems.
abstract: Close look at the details of American military aid to Egypt shows why relatively modest $1.3 billion may give United States more leverage over the Egyptian military than it may seem; American officials say that what Egypt's generals fear most is the cutoff of hundreds of millions of dollars in mundane but essential maintenance contracts that keep their tanks, fighter jets and helicopters running.
lead_paragraph: The $1.3 billion in annual military aid to Egypt pays for the kind of weapons that its military loves, and may give America more leverage than it seems.

headline.main: Cairo Military Firmly Hooked to U.S. Lifeline
headline.print_headline: Cairo Military Firmly Hooked To U.S. Lifeline

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
